title.narrative: Expanded gender-based violence response to the scale up of protection and life-saving measures of vulnerable populations in Tigray, Ethiopia.

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to provide life-saving interventions to prevent, mitigate and respond to Gender-Based Violence (GBV) in conflict-affected communities across Tigray Region. This UNFPA project will establish and strengthen comprehensive service provision for GBV survivors to provide life-saving services, including health and psychosocial support and referral linkage to other services. Through One-Stop Centers (OSC) (integrated into referral hospitals) in zonal capitals of Tigray, women, and girls survivors will receive GBV case management services, Life-saving medical support, mental health referrals, and provision of psychosocial support to women and girls at risk of GBV. This project will offer sexual and reproductive (SRH) health services through women and girls safe spaces (WGSS) throughout IDPs and host communities and provide dignity kits to women and girls of reproductive age to address their menstrual hygiene and self-care needs. The project provides life-saving assistance to136572 people, including 61664 women, 20320 men,54588 children, and 13,742 people with disabilities.

owner-org.narrative: UN OCHA Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF)

organisation.narrative: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA)

mailing-address.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF), 2 United Nations Plaza (DC2), East 44th street (13th floor), United Nations, New York, USA

description.narrative: Disbursement to CERF Project Expanded gender-based violence response to the scale up of protection and life-saving measures of vulnerable populations in Tigray, Ethiopia.

title.narrative: RESIDENT / HUMANITARIAN COORDINATOR REPORT ON THE USE OF CERF FUNDS ETHIOPIA RAPID RESPONSE VIOLENCE/CLASHES 2021

condition.narrative: CERF funding is based on an agreed proposal, including specific planned outcomes and outputs.

description.narrative: GBV survivors have access to comprehensive survivor centred care through one stop centres at government referral facilities
Number of women receiving services at extended OSC sites
PS.1a Number of people benefitting from safe spaces and/or centres (Number of women and girls accessing care at the OSC who indicate satisfaction with the service (80%))
PS.1b Number of safe spaces and/or centres constructed or rehabilitated (# of one stop centres supported to provide comprehensive services)
Women and girls have safe access to psychosocial support, including case management and referrals, through women and girl’s safe spaces (WGSS).
PS.1a Number of people benefitting from safe spaces and/or centres (# of women and girls at risk of GBV and survivors receiving psychosocial support through WGSS)
Percentage of GBV survivors who are linked to at least one other sector for additional support (ex. health, legal)
Women and girls in hard to reach areas have access to basic GBV prevention and response services

PS.2 Number of people benefitting from core GBV services (e.g. case management, psycho-social support, clinical management of rape, PEP, etc.)(# Beneficiaries accessing services through the mobile teams with embedded GBV service provision. (15,120 through community outreach) (37,800 through PSS))
SP.1b Number of people benefiting from menstrual hygiene management kits and/or dignity kits (dignity kits)
